text: here's a neat little demo that shows the
power of electromagnetics I've got a
little triple-a battery here with two
very strong neodymium magnets on the
ends of it and when I put it into this
copper coil that I won't check out what
happens it's sort of like a little train
and this demo made the rounds on the
internet recently I thought I'd have a
go at myself and it works better than
you might think but the trick is making
this coil let's try it again as you can
see the magnets are quite strong and you
saw it got stuck on the screw head
that's in the table here these magnets
are quite powerful they're neodymium
magnets and you need to really have a
strong magnetic field to make this work
so what's happening here is the the
magnets are conductive electrically and
the battery is you know positive
terminal here negative terminal here so
when this thing is inside the copper
coil it's actually conducting current
from one ends to the other and the
current flowing through the copper coil
creates a magnetic field but then these
magnets here oppose that field they push
against that field that's being created
by the electricity and that's what
propels the thing forward so if I get
out some of this magnetic viewer film
you can see the field lines created by
those permanent magnets
I made the copper coil on my lathe and I
started with a half-inch diameter piece
of aluminum and drilled a hole in it and
then started the lathe spinning slowly
in Reverse and used a leather glove to
sort of pull the wire as it was being
wound onto the aluminum rod the magnet
diameter is exactly 1/2 inch and so when
you winds the wire on a half-inch
diameter aluminum rod when you're done
winding the wire will spring back
slightly and make the interior diameter
just slightly larger than half an inch
so all the clearances work out just fine
ok see you next time bye
